newsitem.title: AUSTRALIA: CRICKET-SOHAIL BAN HANDS WEST INDIES FAVOURITISM.
newsitem.headline: CRICKET-SOHAIL BAN HANDS WEST INDIES FAVOURITISM.

text.p: Pakistan captain Wasim Akram conceded on Friday that the loss of suspended opener Aamir Sohail would be a severe blow to his side's chances in the first match of the World Series limited overs final on Saturday.
The dashing left-handed opener was suspended on Friday for one game by match referee Raman Subba Row after questioning an umpire's decision in Pakistan's loss to Australia on Thursday.
West Indies in contrast have been bolstered ahead of the best-of-three finals series by the return to form of star batsman Brian Lara.
"He's our main player, it's tough news," Akram said of Sohail's suspension after the team arrived in Sydney on Friday.
"We are definitely going to miss Aamir tomorrow. We can't play with our proper combination tomorrow, but we've got good back-up and I think we will be okay," he said.
West Indies, after a bad start to the series, have beaten Pakistan three times in four games and have won five of their last six games.
Australia were eliminated from the annual competition last week by a rampant Lara, who blasted 192 runs in two innings against the host nation, capping a remarkable form turn-around.
Lara began his tour of Australia with a wretched series of low scores in both one-day matches and tests, hitting just 139 runs in nine innings over November and December.
But a stunning 102 against Australia on January 5 sparked a purple patch where he scored 295 runs in three games over a one-week period.
The left-hander also plundered Pakistan's attack in scoring 103 not out to lead West Indies to victory last Friday in Perth.
Fast-bowling spearheads Curtly Ambrose and captain Walsh were also rested for that match, devaluing any confidence Pakistan could have taken from the victory.
Walsh told reporters the return of Ambrose after a rest to cure a nagging hamstring injury could be vital.
"He's a class player. When the chips are down, he knows how to get himself back into it. He wasn't having a successful tour, he wasn't taking wickets but now he's Back," Walsh said.
West Indies were also bolstered by the arrival of Phil Simmons early on Friday as a back-up for fellow all-rounders Jimmy Adams, Carl Hooper and Shivnarine Chanderpaul.
